articles.headline: Bread of Life, Baked in Rhode Island
articles.snippet: One company makes about 80 percent of the altar bread used by American churches.
articles.abstract: One company makes about 80 percent of the altar bread used by American churches.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, R.I.  To the Cavanagh family, the product they make at a nondescript plant here is just bread and water. But to millions at churches around the world, it is a sacred offering.

articles.headline: White House Views on Past 8 Years Diverge
articles.snippet: In exit interviews, President Bush sounds reflective, even chastened, while Vice President Dick Cheney is defiant.
articles.abstract: In exit interviews, President Bush sounds reflective, even chastened, while Vice President Dick Cheney is defiant.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney have been unusually talkative in recent weeks, sharing candid thoughts in a string of exit interviews. But after eight years of a tight partnership that gave Mr. Cheney powerful influence inside the White House, the two are sounding strikingly different notes as they leave office, especially on one of the most fundamental issues of their tenure: their aggressive response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

articles.headline: Market for Corporate Jets Goes Into Free-Fall
articles.snippet: Seven months ago, the very rich were lining up for the ultimate status symbol, but that was another era.
articles.abstract: Seven months ago, the very rich were lining up for the ultimate status symbol, but that was another era.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe General Motors should throw in a fleet of Cadillacs.

articles.headline: Fed Approves GMAC Request to Become a Bank
articles.snippet: The change in status makes the company eligible for bailout money and emergency loans directly from the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: The change in status makes the company eligible for bailout money and emergency loans directly from the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators will permit the financing arm of General Motors to become a bank and gain access to billions of dollars in government aid, a crucial step that will help ensure the survival of the company.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Early Reports Confirm Weak Holiday Shopping
articles.snippet: Foot traffic at retail stores declined 23.7 percent and sales fell 5.3 percent compared with a year ago, according to the research firm ShopperTrak.
articles.abstract: Foot traffic at retail stores declined 23.7 percent and sales fell 5.3 percent compared with a year ago, according to the research firm ShopperTrak.
articles.lead_paragraph: The weekend before Christmas is normally one of the busiest shopping periods of the year. But according to one early report, the number of shoppers declined by double digits this year, auguring a dismal holiday season for retailers when the final numbers come in next month.

articles.headline: Cash Flow From Tajik Migrants Stalls
articles.snippet: Countries like Tajikistan that have come to depend on remittances are feeling the effects of the global financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Countries like Tajikistan that have come to depend on remittances are feeling the effects of the global financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOSH-TEPPA, Tajikistan  In poverty-stricken Tajikistan, the global financial crisis is measured in bags of flour.

articles.headline: Effort Under Way to Sell Madoff Unit
articles.snippet: As the investigation into Bernard L. Madoff’s money management business intensifies, efforts are under way to sell quickly the trading unit, which was once the heart of Mr. Madoff’s operations.
articles.abstract: As the investigation into Bernard L. Madoff’s money management business intensifies, efforts are under way to sell quickly the trading unit, which was once the heart of Mr. Madoff’s operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the investigation into Bernard L. Madoff’s money management business intensifies, efforts are under way to sell quickly the trading unit, which was once the heart of Mr. Madoff’s operations.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Once Trusted Mortgage Pioneers, Now Scrutinized
articles.snippet: Herbert and Marion Sandler, long viewed as model citizens of the mortgage industry, have been swept into the debate over who is to blame.
articles.abstract: Herbert and Marion Sandler, long viewed as model citizens of the mortgage industry, have been swept into the debate over who is to blame.
articles.byline: By Michael Moss and Geraldine Fabrikant

articles.headline: Federal Cases of Stock Fraud Drop Sharply
articles.snippet: U.S. officials are bringing far fewer prosecutions as a result of fraudulent stock schemes than they did eight years ago, raising questions about lax oversight.
articles.abstract: U.S. officials are bringing far fewer prosecutions as a result of fraudulent stock schemes than they did eight years ago, raising questions about lax oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Federal officials are bringing far fewer prosecutions as a result of fraudulent stock schemes than they did eight years ago, according to new data, raising further questions about whether the Bush administration has been too lax in policing Wall Street.

articles.headline: Coal Ash Spill Revives Issue of Its Hazards
articles.snippet: The Tennessee Valley Authority has played down the risks of what may be the nation’s largest spill of coal ash, but there are questions about its potential toxicity.
articles.abstract: The Tennessee Valley Authority has played down the risks of what may be the nation’s largest spill of coal ash, but there are questions about its potential toxicity.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Tenn.  What may be the nation’s largest spill of coal ash lay thick and largely untouched over hundreds of acres of land and waterways Wednesday after a dam broke this week, as officials and environmentalists argued over its potential toxicity.

articles.headline: Von Trapps Reunited, Without the Singing
articles.snippet: The grandson of the singing governess made famous by “The Sound of Music” is taking over the family legacy.
articles.abstract: The grandson of the singing governess made famous by “The Sound of Music” is taking over the family legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOWE, Vt.  When Sam von Trapp, the grandson of Maria, the singing governess made famous by “The Sound of Music,” graduated from college, his father offered him a deal: Sam could do whatever he wanted for 10 years before he had to return home here to run the family’s ski lodge.
